noun.description: Divergence from an established form or standard; lack of conformity, especially to a rule, law, or moral code. Chiefly with with, from, †to, or †unto, specifying the thing diverged from.
Difference or diversity of form, nature, or quality; lack of uniformity between things; inconsistency.

origin: Mid 16th century; earliest use found in John Palsgrave (d. 1554), teacher and scholar of languages. From Middle French difformité, diffourmité difference, alteration, divergence from a standard from post-classical Latin difformitas dissimilarity, diversity from difformis + classical Latin -tās.
